Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Towards Recovery of Biological Information
Award.AbstractNarration:
Baylor College of Medicine is awarded a grant to develop novel techniques of network analysis, rooted on the evolutionary principle of continuity, to tackle the fundamental problems of biological data integration and analysis. A problem in biology is that experimental information accumulates far faster than it can be analyzed. These data are complicated, incomplete, and noisy, slowing down their interpretation, but a major difficulty is that because they arise from different experiments they are analyzed separately, or in small groups. This project aims instead to tie all biological data into one network so that each bit of information is understood in light of all other data. To make this approach feasible we propose a new, efficient use of evolutionary relationships to coalesce experimental results arising from hundreds of species into a single network that, although massive, is still easy to compute over. Another insight is that neighboring regions of the network are likely to carry out related biological functions. This hypothesis translates into precise mathematical rules to spread information across the entire network and, as much as possible, resolve contradictions. In practice, these network and computational tools will predict various aspects of protein function that will then be tested experimentally across a broad range of applications (p53, a central gene in animal biology; in proteins that regulate stress adaptation in bacteria; and in malarial proteins). Together computation and experiments will assess the value and limitations of this novel and versatile network approach to discover the molecular origin of function in any organism.

The project will fulfill many goals of broader societal significance. First, it will validate novel techniques of biological network analysis that can be used in any area touched by research in molecular biology; this includes biotechnology, bioengineering, nanotechnology, agriculture, renewable energy production, and synthetic biology applications for industrial processes. Second, it is also important to note that the scientific results fall in the area of BIG DATA analytics, which cuts across science, finance, social and national defense areas of interest. In that light, third, we note that the projects will train both postdoctoral scientists, graduate students, and offer summer internships to undergraduate students, including some from programs supporting minority education and research, who will therefore be able later to contribute their skills in Big Data analytics to many fields of national interest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RESULTS OF PAST NSF FUNDING PERIOD 

Since 2014, ABI—1356569, titled: “ABI Innovation: Towards Recovery of Biological Information.” has led to 20 peer-reviewed publications and 5 more are pending. These include multiple papers in Cell (2), KDD (2, broad conference on machine learning), PSB (2, an important forum for computational biology), Human Mutation (4), Cancer Research (2), and one in each of Annals of Surgery, Cell Reports, PNAS, and J. Pathology, among others. This grant developed new differential equations to propagate information in biological structures of increasing size and complexity so as to integrate data based on the evolutionary smoothness of sequences and networks. Versatile predictions included: (i) mutational impact in proteins, patients and populations; (ii) the function of a malaria protein, and protein interactions in p53 biology via networks; (iii) a novel adaptive biological process in bacteria. Because these studies were coupled to experimentation, this past work elucidated fundamental aspects of evolution, developed new, validated algorithms, and led to discoveries.

   1. Evolutionary Action (EA).  Most relevant to this proposal, we developed a new calculus of evolution to compute mutational impact. In brief, the Evolutionary Action (EA) of a coding mutation on fitness () is a product of the sensitivity of the mutated site () times the mutation size (). Strikingly, both terms can be approximated:  by the evolutionary importance of that position computed with the Evolutionary Trace (ET) algorithm, and  with (inverse) amino acid substitution log-odds. Since 2014, 12 peer-reviewed papers show EA is accurate and versatile. Critically, in viral, bacterial and human proteins, EA correlates with the loss of molecular function due to mutations. Likewise, EA correlates with clinical morbidity in patients; and, as Fisher predicted in 1930, it correlates exponentially with the frequency of single nucleotide variations in populations. EA accuracy is such that in the last three biennial, blinded competitions it usually outperformed all other algorithms that predict deleterious mutations, as judged by independent assessor. In cancer, EA could stratify survival of patients with head and neck tumors, based on p53 mutational status, including lack of response to cisplatin and responsiveness to Wee-1 inhibitors. This EA-p53 stratification of survival was also seen in stage IV colorectal cancer, post-surgical resection of liver metastasis. EA was also helped elucidate liver cancer genes (Cell 2017).

2. Function Prediction.  Since 2014, 5 peer-reviewed publications developed techniques to propagate information across networks to annotate function, and 5 more papers are submitted. A seminal application predicted that the single most cited malarial protein of unknown function, Exp-1, was a putative glutathione-S-transferase (GST). We then showed experimentally that Exp-1 had GST activity, that it was highly reactive with the toxic byproduct of heme metabolism by malaria, hematin, and that it was inhibited by the best current anti-malarial drug, Artemisinin—a herbal-derived compound of unclear mechanism (Cell 2014). This approach is being extended to unstructured data (i.e. text) and heterogeneous data types (genes, diseases, and drugs) to create multimodal networks, upon which we apply collaborative filtering (non-negative matrix factorization) and community detection algorithms. In so doing, we discovered and experimentally validated new p53 kinases (including NEK2 and members of the PAK family, in preparation). These data show that biological information flows smoothly across complex networks structures, and we can exploit this fact to transfer annotation across nodes, even if these nodes represent distinct types of entities. Moreover these networks can be built from text mining as well as from databases, leading to a general and unified framework to generate automated hypotheses from both unstructured and structured data—so far, a major bottleneck in knowledge integration.

  3. Mutational robustness by negative autoregulatory feedback. In one paper, we found a new evolutionary mechanism in which the self-correcting, negative-feedback gene regulation motif increases mutational robustness (Cell Reports 2014). In a second paper, we predicted that robustness of the negative feedback is characterized by three parameters: the cooperativity coefficient in self-repression, the maximal expression rate constant of the transcription factor, and the apparent dissociation constant of the transcription factor binding to its own promoter; and this was then shown experimentally in the LexA transcriptional network of E. coli by altering cooperativity in self-repression and promoter strength (Phys Rev Let 2016). Before then, only chaperones were known to epigenetically rescue function in proteins with deleterious mutations. This new mechanism operates across Eubacteria, as seen from the greater accumulation of amino acid substitutions in negative-feedback transcription factors. Together, these data show that a ubiquitous network control system, negative feedback, increases mutational tolerance. Because mutations determine the heritable variations upon which natural selection acts, the ability of gene network wiring to reshape the mutational landscape of a protein could significantly influence the course of evolution. As such, negative feedback is a self-contained genetic canalization mechanism that preserves phenotype while permitting access to a wider range of functional genotypes.
